DRM101Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM101Y1-Y-20209.courseTitle: Introduction to Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM101Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: The course introduces students to key concepts and issues in the three related disciplines at the core of our program: drama, theatre, and performance studies. We consider broader questions of performance and performativity in daily life alongside the questions of what goes into the making of a stage-based performance and the responsibilities of artists, presenters, and witnesses in this endeavour. Engaging critically with theoretical and dramatic texts and live performances, students learn how to think about performance in its cultural, social, aesthetic and political dimensions, and how to acknowledge and navigate their own responsibilities as culture workers situated in specific historical and contemporary contexts. This course combines weekly two-hour lectures with one-hour tutorials.
DRM101Y1-Y-20209.exclusion: DRM100Y1, DRE121H5, DRE122H5, VPDA10H3, VPDA11H3, VPDA10H3, VPDA15H3, VPDB10H3, VPDB11H3
DRM101Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Students must sign up for a tutorial. They will be informed of their assigned tutorial room in the first week of class.
DRM101Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Tuesday 9am -11am EST) and one online tutorial (Tuesday 11am-12pm or 12-1pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.
DRM101Y1-Y-20209.breadthCategories: Creative and Cultural Representations (1), Society and its Institutions (3)

DRM200Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM200Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: Emphasis is initially placed on ensemble, non-verbal, and improvisational work. Students proceed to the application of their acquired skills to scripted material. Students may apply in their first or second year of University. The Application Deadline is March 10th for the first round of auditions; August 10th for the second round. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
DRM200Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: An audition and interview in April or in August. Newly admitted students can apply for an audition before beginning their first year of studies.
DRM200Y1-Y-20209.exclusion: DRS221H5 AND DRS222H5; VPDB01H3 AND VPDB02H3
DRM200Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on an audition & interview. Priority is reserved for Drama Majors and Specialists. First round of applications were due March 10th. The second round application (including audition video) is due by August 10th, followed by an online interview in mid-August. Students can apply straight out of high school: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM200Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes and in-person or workshops and group work sessions. Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM202H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM202H1-F-20209.courseDescription: A practical introduction to directing theatre and to the different styles, concerns, and goals that can guide directors in their relations to actors, audiences, and politics. Through lectures, discussions, and practical exercises, students learn how directors prepare for their work in terms of generating ideas, breaking down a text, animating space, and communicating with actors and audiences.
DRM202H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Specialist or Major in Drama; DRM101Y1
DRM202H1-F-20209.recommendedPreparation:
DRM100Y1/DRM101Y1/UNI102Y1

Distribution Requirement: Humanities

Breadth Requirement: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)
DRM202H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.
DRM202H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Monday 5-8pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM220Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM220Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: This course will introduce students to major developments in world theatre history through the exploration of a wide range of plays, performances, and practices. In the Fall term our trajectory will go roughly from antiquity to the 16th Century; in the Winter term, from the 16th Century to the present. We will examine material from Africa, America, Asia, Europe, and Oceania, with close attention to the social, religious, historical, aesthetic, and political parameters in which theatre and performance take place. Nurturing ethnically sensitive approaches to world theatre history, this course considers the many ways theatre and performance interact with the globalized world. Students will have an opportunity to participate in collaborative projects and focus on writing for research in the performing arts.
DRM220Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Tuesday 10am -12pm EST) and tutorials (Tuesday 12-1pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM228H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM228H1-S-20209.courseDescription: A hands-on study of the craft of dramatic writing. The class examines the basic elements of playwriting such as plot, structure, theme, character, dialogue, setting, with an emphasis on story-making. Attention is given to the development of students own work through written assignments and in-class exercises.
DRM228H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Specialist or Major in Drama; DRM101Y1
DRM228H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.
DRM228H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM254H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM254H1-F-20209.courseDescription: A practical and theoretical introduction to the fundamentals of theatrical performance design. This course touches on theatre architecture, conceptual approaches to theatrical design and spatial considerations of live performance. Students will work on case studies and practical projects geared toward understanding theatre terminology, design, and production processes. Students will also explore concrete aspects of technical theatre production, particularly as they pertain to theatrical design elements.
DRM254H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca.
DRM254H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Wednesday 10AM-1PM EST) and tutorials/ group work sessions (Monday 10AM-12PM EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM300Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM300Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: Building upon the work of DRM200Y1, students concentrate on scene study, styles of acting, and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices. The Application Deadline is March 10th.
DRM300Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1 and DRM200Y1
DRM300Y1-Y-20209.corequisite: DRM220Y1 or any course from Group A if DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 is complete
DRM300Y1-Y-20209.recommendedPreparation: and the development of ensemble work with an intensive focus on voice and movement practices.The
DRM300Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM300Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes and in-person or workshops and group work sessions. Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM302H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM302H1-S-20209.courseDescription: A continuation of DRM202H1, concentrating on deepening the exploration of what it means to think and work like a director. Through practical exercises and scene study, students learn how to conceptualize a production and how to communicate their vision, as well as deepen their understanding of what is involved in directing actors and collaborating with a production team. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.
DRM302H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1; DRM202H1; and an interview in November.
DRM302H1-S-20209.corequisite: DRM220Y1 or any course from Group A.
DRM302H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on an interview. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply by November 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM302H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes and group work sessions. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM320H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM320H1-F-20209.courseTitle: Concepts of Theatre in the Twentieth and Twenty-first Centuries
DRM320H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An exploration of the shifting landscapes of European theatre theory, history and practice in the late 19th century and their repercussions throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. The course focuses on the developments of modern and post-dramatic theatre. It also includes critical analysis of the annual Drama Mainstage production and current Canadian theatre.
DRM320H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Tuesday 10am -12pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM328H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM328H1-F-20209.courseDescription: A continuation of DRM228H1, concentrating on the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own work through written assignments, in-class exercises, and the final public presentation. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply and the deadline to apply.
DRM328H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1; DRM228H1; and  a portfolio of writing samples due in April.
DRM328H1-F-20209.corequisite: DRM220Y1 or any course from Group A
DRM328H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on a portfolio submission. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM328H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Tuesday 6-9PM EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM331H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM331H1-F-20209.courseDescription: Study of dramaturgical theory and of interpretations of the dramaturge's function in the theatre. Using examples from Canada and beyond, students apply this knowledge to theatre practice.
DRM331H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous online course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Wednesday 6-9pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM342H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM342H1-F-20209.courseDescription: The turn of the 21st century advanced a social, political, and aesthetic shift reminiscent of that during the post-Industrial Revolution/pre-WWII epoch that launched the historical avant-garde. This class, while exploring significant artistic and sociopolitical developments of the historical avant-garde, will primarily concentrate on the experimental theatre and performance of the past 15 yearsa contemporary avant-garde that hinge[s] on a networked spatiality, rather than on linear teleology and reflects a growing collective investment on part of audiences and artists alike in the work of a work of art.
DRM342H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Monday 2-4pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM354H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM354H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An intermediate-level investigation of various aspects of theatrical performance design, with a focus on scenic and costume design, though also considering the impact of projections and lighting. Using skills developed through practical study in the Design Studio, the students form the core of the design team for Drama productions. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM354H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1; DRM254H1; and an interview.
DRM354H1-S-20209.corequisite: DRM220Y1 or any course from Group A
DRM354H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on an interview. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM354H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes and group work sessions. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM355Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM355Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: An intermediate-level investigation of various aspects of theatrical production, including stage management, lighting, sound and video, with some exploration of how these elements relate to theatrical design concepts. Using skills developed through practical study in the Helen Gardiner Phelan Playhouse, the students form the core of the production team for Drama productions. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM355Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1; DRM254H1; and an interview.
DRM355Y1-Y-20209.corequisite: DRM220Y1 or any course from Group A
DRM355Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on an interview. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM355Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person or classes (Tuesday and Thursday 2-4pm EST). In the winter term, the course will also require participation in synchronous online or in-person tutorials (Tuesday and Thursday 4-5pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM375H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM375H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor. Please check Studio Topics on the CDTPS undergraduate web page for more details.
DRM375H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses:  DRM101Y1; DRM200Y1/DRM202H1/DRM228H1/DRM254H1
DRM375H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: To enroll in DRM375H1, you must have taken DRM200Y1 as a prerequisite. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca
DRM375H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes, tutorials and group work sessions (Tuesday 5-8PM EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM376H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM376H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor. Please check Studio Topics on the CDTPS undergraduate web page for more details.
DRM376H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM101Y1; DRM200Y1/DRM202H1/DRM228H1/DRM254H1
DRM376H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: To enroll in DRM376H1, you must have taken DRM200Y1, DRM202H1, DRM228H1 or DRM254H1 as a prerequisite. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca
DRM376H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM377H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM377H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected performance disciplines, styles, and genres within their historical and critical context. Content may vary depending on instructor. Please check Studio Topics on the CDTPS undergraduate web page for more details.
DRM377H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: To enroll in DRM377H1, you must have taken DRM101Y1, DRM200Y1, DRM202H1, DRM228H1 or DRM254H1 as a prerequisite. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca
DRM377H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Zoom and Bb Collaborate.

DRM386H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM386H1-S-20209.courseTitle: Special Topics in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM386H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected issues in drama, theatre and performance studies. Special Topics vary for Breadth distribution depending on the course content. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office and check Special Topics on the website for more details.
DRM386H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM388H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM388H1-S-20209.courseTitle: Special Topics in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM388H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected issues in drama, theatre and performance studies. Special Topics vary for Breadth distribution depending on the course content. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office and check Special Topics on the website for more details.
DRM388H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to attend synchronous online classes (with the knowledge that the instructor may cancel a synchronous class occasionally). The classes will mostly be discussion- or presentation-based depending on the time of the semester. There will be required asynchronous lectures to supplement some weeks readings that will be uploaded to Quercus. Students will need access to high-speed internet, a microphone, and a keyboard to participate fully in this class. Although a webcam is not required, (there will be different ways to participate in discussion) a microphone is required.

DRM400H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM400H1-F-20209.courseDescription: Advanced Performance builds on the training sequence of DRM200Y1 and DRM300Y1 by developing students acting and performance skills in monologues, extensive collaborative scene work, and preparations for auditions. The work focuses on the particulars of character development and the emotional and technical aspects of the actors craft. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM400H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1
DRM400H1-F-20209.corequisite: DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre
DRM400H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Tuesday and Thursday 2-4pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM402H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM402H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An exploration of advanced directing for the theatre. The class is centered on student directed productions, which are publicly presented at the end of term. Emphasis is placed on the development of strong central concepts and realizing the production with imagination, collaboration and creativity. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM402H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM302H1; DRM331H1; a written proposal and an interview in April.
DRM402H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Drama Majors and Specialists can apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be determined based on student availability.
DRM402H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Wednesday 2-5pm EST) and tutorials (Wednesday, 5-6pm EST).   Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM403Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM403Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: This course, taught each year by a different visiting professional theatre director, offers upper-level theatre and performance studies students the opportunity to explore acting in a full-length production. Plays are selected to challenge students in a variety of diverse ways, exposing them to a full spectrum of theatre and performance genres and possibilities. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM403Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1, 0.5 FCE from DRM368H1/DRM375H1/DRM376H1/DRM377H1/DRM378H1.
DRM403Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Drama Majors and Specialists can apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly in the second term. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability.
DRM403Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Monday and Wednesday 10-1pm EST). In the winter term, the course will also require participation in synchronous online or in-person tutorials (Friday 10-1pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM413H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM413H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Voice and Movement is a skill-developing companion to the DRM400H1 training for performers. It exposes students to a wide range of voice and movement techniques and explores a heightened use of physicality, voice and speech.
DRM413H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/ DRM230Y1; DRM300Y1
DRM413H1-S-20209.corequisite: DRM403Y1 or permission of the Centre
DRM413H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to a yoga mat, high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM420H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM420H1-S-20209.courseTitle: Arts and Politics: Bertolt Brecht, Giorgio Strehler, Robert Wilson and Robert Lepage
DRM420H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Bertolt Brecht played a specific role in the paradigm shift of the art which began at the end of the 19th century. He advanced this change by trying to connect art to its social and political functions and structure with the positive acceptance of the industrial revolution and by trying to transform it with the help of the new technological media.
DRM420H1-S-20209.prerequisite: 9 FCE; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1 or DRM320H1; Specialist or Major in Drama
DRM420H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Zoom.

DRM428H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM428H1-S-20209.courseDescription: A continuation of DRM328H1, concentrating upon the in-depth knowledge and practice of playwriting with an emphasis on advanced style and technique of writing for the stage. Students develop their own longer work through in-class exercises, one major written assignment, and the final public presentation. Please consult the CDTPS undergraduate web page for information on how to apply.
DRM428H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1, DRM328H1 and a portfolio of writing samples due in November.
DRM428H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on an portfolio submission. Apply online by November 10th. https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login There will be additional tutorial times which will be held regularly. Dates and times to be determined based on student availability.
DRM428H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM431H1-S-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM431H1-S-20209.courseDescription: A continuation of DRM331H1 Dramaturgy. Students will be provided with finer conceptual tools with which to approach DRM402H1 Advanced Directing and DRM403Y1 Mainstage Performance.
DRM431H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes. Students need access to high-speed internet service, a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Zoom and a live streaming application (Youtube, Twitch etc.)

DRM454H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM454H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An advanced-level exploration of theatrical design skills and techniques, delving deeper into specific areas of specialization and with more opportunity for independent work. Students are expected to participate in Drama Centre productions in senior creative and leadership roles. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM454H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1;  DRM354H1/DRM354Y1; and an interview.
DRM454H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Wednesday 2-4pm EST) and in a one-hour tutorial per week to work on group projects (Tuesday 11am-12pm or 12-1pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM455H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM455H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An advanced-level exploration of production skills and techniques, delving deeper into specific areas of specialization and with more opportunity for independent work. Students are expected to participate in Drama Centre productions in senior creative and leadership roles. Applications are required in order to enroll in this course. Please consult the CDTPS Application Guidelines for specific procedures and deadlines.
DRM455H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Minimum 70% in required courses: DRM220Y1/ DRM230Y1; DRM355Y1; and an interview.
DRM455H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Selection is based on an interview. Priority is given to Drama Majors and Specialists. Apply by March 10th: https://drama-apply.chass.utoronto.ca/login
DRM455H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is a dual delivery course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online or in-person classes (Wednesday 2-4pm EST) and in a one-hour tutorial per week to work on group projects (Tuesday 11am-12pm or 12-1pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM487H1-F-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM487H1-F-20209.courseTitle: Senior Seminar in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM487H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An in-depth examination of selected issues in the theatre at the 400 level. Special Topics vary for Breadth distribution depending on the course content and therefore may be counted towards Groups A or B. Please consult the Undergraduate Drama office or check the programs website for more details.
DRM487H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Specialist or Major in Drama; 14 FCE; DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1.
DRM487H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: This is an online synchronous course. Students will be required to participate in synchronous online classes (Monday 6-8pm EST). Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.

DRM490Y1-Y-20209.orgName: Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies, Centre for (DRM) (JDC) (JIA)
DRM490Y1-Y-20209.courseTitle: Independent Studies in Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies
DRM490Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: A scholarly project at the 400 level proposed by the individual student in conversation with a member of faculty who is willing to act as supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
DRM490Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: 14 FCE; Specialist or Major in Drama; Minimum 70% in DRM220Y1/DRM230Y1; A written proposal; Independent study form signed by both student and faculty instructor to be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) before registration: August 1st for September start date; November 1st for January start date.
DRM490Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: A written proposal and an independent study form signed by the faculty member who has agreed to supervise the project must be submitted for approval to the Associate Director (undergraduate) by August 1st.  For more information, please contact Colleen Osborn at c.osborn@utoronto.ca
DRM490Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Assignments will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need a webcam and microphone (can be built-in) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate and Zoom.
